bestBHT.bht: Martha, not habituated herself to listen to Jesus's instructions, secretly called her sister Mary to avoid the Jews present and informants. Mary went to meet Jesus upon receiving the news that The Master is come and calleth for thee, giving us a glimpse into the private interchange among Jesus and his disciples. This title, The Master, reflects the high esteem in which Jesus was held by those devoted to him, and Mary's immediate response reveals her deep reverence and unwavering faith in him.

Henry Alford: Her calling her sister is characteristic of one who (as in Luke x. 40) had not been much habituated herself to listen to his instructions.
Secretly] 'Lest the Jews who were present should know it, and should perhaps give information against Him to those who were conspiring against His life.'
But is it not somewhat too plainly asserted, to mean only calling by inference? Surely, we must regard Martha’s words as proving it to have been a fact.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: calleth for thee—The narrative does not give us this
interesting detail, but Martha's words do.
Albert Barnes: She went her way - Jesus probably directed her to go, though the evangelist has not recorded it, for she said to Mary, The Master calleth for thee.

Secretly - Privately. So that the others did not hear her. This was done, perhaps, to avoid confusion, or because it was probable that if they knew Jesus was coming they would have made opposition. Perhaps she doubted whether Jesus desired it to be known that he had come.

The Master is come - This appears to have been the appellation by which he was known to the family. It means, literally, teacher, and was a title which he claimed for himself. 'One is your Master, even Christ' Matthew 23:8, Matthew 23:10.
Marvin Vincent: The Master [ο διδασκαλος]...opens a glimpse into the private intercourse of the Lord and the disciples: so they spoke of Him.
The Master...so they spoke of Him.
John Calvin: The word Master shows in what estimation Christ was held among those pious women.
It was a great matter that they were entirely devoted to him as his disciples.
Mary’s sudden departure, to come and meet him, was a proof that she regarded him with no ordinary reverence.
Philip Schaff: We cannot doubt that Mary until now had been in ignorance of the coming of Jesus."
That which He was about to do He would have faith, not unbelief, to see.
Archibald T. Robertson: Called Mary... Out of the house and away from the crowd."
Secretly... To tell her the glad news."
The Master... So they loved to call him as he was... Is here... Calleth thee. This rouses Mary.
John Gill: Had expressed her faith in Christ in such terms, as the apostles themselves did.
She went her way... and called Mary her sister secretly.
The master is come... and calleth for thee.

bhtAttempts.bht: Martha, not being accustomed to listening to Jesus's teachings, secretly called her sister Mary, perhaps to avoid the Jews who were present and might report to those conspiring against Jesus. Her words, The Master is come and calleth for thee, open a glimpse into the private interchange between Jesus and his disciples, as they lovingly referred to him as the Master. Mary, unaware of Jesus's coming, eagerly went to meet him, demonstrating her deep reverence and faith in him. The title Master reflects the high regard in which Jesus was held by those devoted to him, and Mary's immediate response highlights her unwavering belief in him.

Martha, not accustomed to listening to Jesus, secretly called her sister Mary, perhaps to avoid the Jews present and informants. Mary eagerly went to meet Jesus upon hearing the news that The Master is come and calleth for thee, revealing the private interchange between Jesus and his disciples, who lovingly referred to him as the Master. Mary's immediate response displayed her unwavering belief in Jesus, affirming the high regard and reverence she held for him.

This title, The Master, reflects the high esteem in which Jesus was held by those devoted to him, and Mary's immediate response reveals her deep reverence and unwavering faith in him.

This title, The Master, reflects the high esteem in which Jesus was held by those devoted to him, and Mary's immediate response reveals her deep reverence and unwavering faith in him.

Mary eagerly went to meet Jesus upon hearing the news that The Master is come and calleth for thee, revealing the private interchange between Jesus and his disciples, who lovingly referred to him as the Master.
